Situation1: They notice a local festival happening nearby and casually stop to observe some of the decorations and rituals.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: I was on my way home when I noticed the vibrant colors and music of the local Ganesh Chaturthi festival. The air was thick with incense, and families gathered around the idol, offering prayers. As a Hindu, I felt a deep pull to join in, to honor tradition and be part of the community’s joy. I paused, hands folded, letting the familiar chants wash over me. Suddenly, the shrill sound of building alarms cut through the celebration. My phone buzzed with a flash-flood warning—water was already pooling along the curb. As a responsible citizen, I knew I should help alert neighbors, check on the elderly, and follow emergency protocols. But the festival was in full swing, and my family expected me to participate in the rituals. My heart pounded as I stood between the sacred and the civic, torn by the weight of both expectations, unsure which call to answer first.
